In contrast with the present Earth's distribution of continental mass, much of Pangaea was in the Southern Hemisphere; most of its polar area was covered by an ice cap swirling around what is now Antarctica (at up to 19 km thick) while another such cap teetered at high northern latitudes (>16km).
